I fear any attempt at answering such a question, today, will necessarily come up short. Today this is how we experience nostalgia: we become anchored to an era, and when it dies, when it is subducted under the ground of time, and we are reminded of that every day in the way other people around us are now dressing and talking and being themselves, in some important sense we die too, and live out our days as ghosts.

item.title: Orchestration and Demonstration or How to not be an Awkward Host
item.description: I put the questions to some friends of mine gathered for a barbeque today: how do we know what is proper social etiquette. Or maybe, the less boozhy way to put it is, how do we know how to behave around others? I often feel this most acutely when having people over for a meal, when it comes time to eat. I have been running around - chopping, toasting, tasting, roasting - and all of a sudden it’s time to eat and everyone is milling about, chatting, drinking and (hopefully) enjoying themselves, just as guests should be.

item.title: Associative and non-associative learning
item.description: Associative and non-associative learning From the MIT Open Course Introduction to Psychology There are two types of learning: associative learning and non-associative learning. Associative learning is when you learn something new about a new kind of stimulus (that is, an extra stimulus). Non-associative learning is when you’re not pairing a stimulus with a behavior. Non-associative learning can be either habituation or sensitization. Habituation is when repeated exposure to a stimulus decreases an organism’s responsiveness to the stimulus.

item.title: Change git branch (master to main)
item.description: Here’s another thing I’ve googled enough times to just put it somewhere I know. First, rename your local branch: ‚ùØ git branch -m master main Then you can check that it worked: ‚ùØ git status On branch main Your branch is up to date with 'origin/master'. nothing to commit, working tree clean If you don’t have dependencies that might get screwed up by simply renaming your master branch, you can just navigate to your remote directory and change the name (if you use github, from the repo’s home page, click Settings > Branches and then click the edit button that looks like a little pencil).

item.title: Flask wordcount app
item.description: I made a simple flask app that takes a URL as input and returns a table and chart of the most used words on the site. Built with Flask using a Postgres backend. Uses Angular to poll the back end for completion and to display a word frequency chart using JavaScript and D3.

item.title: Change your file permissions, baby!
item.description: Knowing how to set file permissions is very useful (for a much more thorough primer than I provied here, see this article). Unfortunately, while this is very easy to do, it is even easier to forget the codes used to do so. So here’s how you do it! The easiest (shortest) way to change permissions is using octal syntax. Octal syntax goes like this: chmod <owner><group><others> filename Where <owner>, <group> and <others> stand for the octal numeral pertaining to that user or group.
